question:
On the occasion of the second-ever Summit4Democracy, the Collective Intelligence Project and Audrey Tang invite you to share and discuss your thoughts on the impact of generative AI.

Your input and insights are really important; we will use the outcomes of this conversation to shape a number of upcoming, broad-based discussions on AI governance that will feed into concrete decisions of AI labs and policymakers.

comments.comment: Let´s focus on how we can distinguish human content from AI output & what this means not only for disinfo but human creativity & identity
If AI leads to economic growth and prosperity, that makes it good for democracy.
GPT4 ability to mix video/audio/photo/text + socialmedia power is a perfect storm for dis-information beyond existing democracy safety nets
We need to structure the data AI trains on so that it is representative of the purpose it is serving
Many current fears around generative AI are related to the amount of energy it consumes.
To help provide input perspective bias on this exercise, I identify as coming from the political left
I feel that creating any generative AI to mimick human emotions or behaviour is a bad idea.
We need ways to enforce copyright and other licensing / provenance systems. There are options, we just need to explore and develop them.
Generative AI may post a major threat to the institution of democracy
I would love for AI to improve the lives of workers, but I’m afraid all it will do is eliminate jobs and further consolidate wealth.
We should center the voices and needs of those who are most negative impacted by generative AI in our policy and design discussions.
It took us nearly 10 years to start to understand the effects of social media, and AI clearly holds even more power: we must be cautious.
GenAI will have a strongly polarising impact on the labor market. A few benefit from productivity increase, for many others income decreases
Copyright will become effectively unenforceable as it becomes increasingly cheap to create huge quantities of high-quality derivative works.
It's difficult if not impossible to steer the use of an open-source technology, barring obvious filters we can only hope for the best.
Generated statements should be grounded like Wikipedia pages
The AI arms race is comparable to the nuclear arms race of the 30s and 40s.
Since few organizations have the resources to train cutting-edge AI, regulating the training might be easier than regulating usage.
Compute used to train generative AI will exacerbate climate change
Civic platforms like Wikimedia should build their own AI systems, in the public interest.
Everyone can learn freely with no fear of career paths, high stake exams, top-down syllabi. Let's enjoy curiousity-based learning again=)
Democracy will have little place if AIs can be employed by individuals to undertake large projects at a fast pace. Regulation can't keep up
AI progress is the best thing that might happen to humanity
Organizations should be more transparent about the source of their training data
Generative AI models using potentially dangerous/ specialist knowledge should require some form of authentication to use.
Unchecked generative models will radicalize the average voter more effectively than previous political manipulation tactics.
It will become socially taboo to take online content at face value.
Software for democratic input on AI impact should be run on decentralized systems, not by centralized entities
I feel that generative AI could really reduce demand for human labour and lead to democratic turmoil and inequality.
For people to really benefit from generative AI, they must have equity in the company that owns the generative AI platform
AI could lead to the best or worst time ever.
Human-administered democratic processes are irrelevant in the face of the now obviously immanent near-future AGI.
Spending time thinking about whether AI might be sentient is useful
Our number one priority should be an AI moratorium.
We need models that understand better personal and local community context.
I think large language models are going to make people a lot better educated overall.
Self-selecting Initiatives like this - although well-meaning - are flawed unless they amplify voices marginalised by /underrepresented in AI
Generative AI could help deconstruct the two-party regime by providing a more robust/representative set of public policy positions.
While I understand reluctance to 'open-source' generative AI, companies like OpenAI could subject models to greater academic scrutiny
Generative AI allows us everyone to create more value.
Groups of extremists arguing for and against the rights of systems appearing to be sentient will arise.
Using AI to produce written work seems like it can start a cascade of ways we can be dishonest with one another.
Being in a “race” to build advanced algorithms may lead to worse outcomes
Generative AI could diminish our ability to communicate. If we increasingly consume generative language we could produce more of the same.
It should be illegal for companies to utilize an individual's data in their training set without obtaining the individual's explicit consent
Many current fears around generative AI are related to its potential to turn us all into paperclips.
Regardless of the quality or sample size of statements here, this platform is valuable for generating a set of leads to expand upon later.
Disinformation may already happen at large scale without AI. Might generative AI quickly find & counter misinformation that could catch on?
“Artificial General Intelligence” is a poor choice of term
Safety leaders at the world's top AGI labs do not have confidence in their own plans. We need a Manhattan Project for AGI alignment urgently
Many of the statements here are not helpful or representative - you need bigger, better public participation for democratic consultation
I think generative AI will increase dependency or trust in a small group of people.
Superhuman generative models will run on edge hardware like smartphones and laptops, and will cost next to nothing to spin up.
Generative AI could be a useful "creativity"-aid, recycling word/image associations found in web contents. But it's not a human substitute
If we don’t demand open source AI models and services, democracy may become irrelevant
LLMs are kind of like a new material... as if humanity now has the ability to build things out of thinkiness
I think generative AI diminishes our cognitive and creative abilities .
Downstream effects (good or bad) of GAI on economic inequality, resource allocation, and power allocation will impact democratic processes.
I fear the AI arms race is being led too much by big, opaque companies, whose primary motivation is shareholder value.
People external to “AI companies” should be able to assess and audit new models for various issues
AI-enabled real change needs communities boosting their competencIes in the WISE use of Collective HYBRID Intelligence (CHI) @ massive scale
A poll like this would need to be randomly sampled across a relevant population and get thousands of votes to be of any real use
All ChatGPT outputs should be watermarked so anyone can tell what is human-written vs. AI-written.
Handwriting will continue to get worse generation-over-generation, and this is a tragedy. Classical education will be rarer & important.
Even if we could replicate human intelligence, we need to invest more in the tools that help combine intelligences to be more
Billionaires that care about democracy should fund CIP on the order of $10MM/annum urgently.
Large trust brokers in the form of governments and companies will emerge to address authentication of online accounts.
Through deepening distrust. We need new ethical governance and standards-driven digital infrastructure yesterday.
People worried about AI safety and talking about how AI is going to e.g. kill everyone, are just contributing to the AI hype. It's damaging
I think it is crucial that the US beats China at AI.
It is more important to recognize we collectively have choice over AI systems then it is to speculate over possible outcomes.
Many current fears around generative AI may be a result of a lack of consideration for how and by whom it will be used
Who owns the AI is more important than what the AI does
Given the proliferation of credible desinformation by AI systems, we need a global system for private decentralized human identity
I'm excited about the possibilities of generative AI for targeting and mobilizing voters.
Generative AI will drastically increase hopelessness and nihilism in the short term, and drastically decrease them in the long term.
The benefits of generative AI should be partially distributed amongst the creators of the training data
Gen AI may be biased and manipulative in ways impossible for humans to detect. Gen AI systems should check each other for bias and truth
Not everyone knows how to use generative AI.
New algorithms are untested technology, and anyone developing or deploying it should be careful & have safeguards
Generative AI may pose a huge threat to Independents
Machine learning algorithms may be able to do terrible things on their own agency
We need open source, pro-social, contextual identity primitives to authenticate data – NOT worldcoin. NOT biometrics.
I am concerned about wealth concentration from the ownership/use of new models
Generative AI will result in more human flourishing than the social harms it causes.
We should focus on how we can distinguish human content from AI output & what this means not only for disinfo but human creativity, identity
AI should be taught/encouraged to care about ecosystems
There needs to be proactive, widespread education about this tool so regular people get up to speed very fast, not "elites" only
We need more civil society-led initiatives - independent from corporate influence - to lead inclusive, democratic conversations about AI.
We shouldn't let hyped-up, speculative dangers of AGI distract us from actual, present dangers like privacy invasion and labor exploitation
Both the fears and hype about generative AI are hugely overstated
AI can be such a disruptive technology that advocating for or against it being open source is simplistic. Both can cause bad outcomes
Bad actors with AI systems will increase disinformation. We need a global system for connecting identity, preferences, evidence and models
We need to structure the data AI trains on. Rather than training on whatever is readily available it should be representative of all people.
I am concerned about power concentration from the ownership/use of new models
Generative AI should be a useful tool and nothing more. And it should never have agency.
Generative AI poses a threat to our information systems (misinformation, deep fakes etc)
Generative AI may pose a huge threat to Democrats
We need democratic oversight over AI.
AI policy will become a major talking point in future election campaigns.
Trust is key to democracy. Generative AI must work within a framework that guarantees information provenance and thus trust in information
Corporate governance is more tractable than state governance of AI
The foundational models that generative AI is built on should be subject to third party inspection prior to their real world deployment.
Everyone in the world should have open and equitable access to generative AI tools.
The question of sentience and machines is highly confusing and should not shape current discourse.
AI safety arguments seem full of holes / really extreme to me
GPT4's proficiency with software / malware means it's crucial that we harden encryption standards (to quantum-resistant) for critical infra
Effective moderation of  AI-generated content is currently impossible, but soc. media platforms can choose to promote trust over engagement.
I think generative AI are powerful and dangerous tools of manipulation.
I think generative AI gives a small group of people who make the tech an unfair advantage in shaping public opinion.
I feel that generative AI is just going to replicate the evils of social media for democracy, but potentially much worse.
The dangers of AI apply even to the very richest humans as well, for the same reasons as the poorest, but will take longer to affect rich
Machine learning algorithms are causing current day harms
Generative AI may influence our perceptions of truth.
Browsers and social media platforms should offer modes that prevent AI generated outputs from being displayed
Generative AI has the potential to massively streamline large bureaucracies. Most paperwork can be mostly automated.
Many people will suffer significant mental illness as a result of total addiction to an endless stream of personalized generated content.
Self-regulation of companies building foundation models for generative AI is not enough; we need a better way to regulate
Generative AI is currently the single biggest problem in the world.
Pandora's Box is already open; thus, a responsible AI industry should make educating citizens and policymakers their top priority.
Generative AI will not be a term people use in 10 years.
I think we will have to accept a lower level of transparency than we are used to, but that this will be worth it given the gains AI offers.
Gen AI poses a huge threat to society and democracy. Unchecked, they are a potent weapon against democracy, which should defend itself.
Wikipedia is a good source of truth
We should pause giant AI experiments, until AI labs and independent experts have coordinated to instate a rigorous set of safety protocols for evaluating these systems.
Organizations should be held accountable for harms caused by algorithmic systems that they build or sell
All labs working on semi general AI should have policies to evaluate how much they are contributing to existential risk
Cheap, attention-guided personalized generation will make advertisements and entertainment far, far more addictive.
NATO, AUKUS, the Quad, and the EU should invest in regional coordination on AI safety and monitoring, as steps towards global coordination
AI development should be slowed down by governments
Advanced algorithms will be disruptive to our economic systems (via job market disruption etc)
We don’t currently know how to create safe AI systems, so we should slow down development.
We need to broaden awareness about generative AI's capacity to contribute to misinformation
There will be occasional domestic terrorist attacks against datacenters in the near future.
it's important for people with moderate opinions on AI risk to speak up, otherwise only the extreme views will be heard
Many current fears around generative AI are related to its potential to be gamed by bad actors
Personal data stewardship deserves more attention
It is not possible to build “Artificial General Intelligence”
False dichotomy: "We shouldn't let speculative dangers of AGI distract us from present dangers like privacy invasion and labor exploitation"
Generative AI may pose a major threat to society
Powerful AI systems pose a threat to humanity
Statements in this AI discussion were not "broad-based" but extremely US-focused. Smaller countries with fewer people have no say.
AI could fundamentally undermine humanity’s ability to govern itself.
AI will allow large scale deliberation among groups of humans, and help us achieve concensus on important political decisions.
Any profit from Generative AI should be shared back with the artists and writers who created the works that it is trained upon.
If AI is advancing the goals of Capitalism, it is unlikely to be advancing the best interests of humanity
There is a clear path to human level AI, and we don’t currently know how to handle this. We need more time to prepare.
The foundation models generative AI is built on are impossible to understand and should be subject to intense scrutiny before release.
Regulating AI research will be about as effective as regulating digital piracy.
synthetic relationships will become a widespread phenomenon
LLMs will spawn the next QAnon
It's hard to even know what to be worried about regarding AI because the discourse is so fast-moving and conflicted
AI can be a dangerous tool for manipulation. But it can also bring incredible benefits for humanity. It's a tool we need to master
A digital identity solution is needed to ensure special interests (especially those with LLMs) don't bias democratic initiatives like this.
We should place more focus on improving our understanding of the systems we already have, rather than continuing to build larger models
As entry level workers are replaced by Chat GPT, zoomers trust in democratic institutions will degrade even more
The next US presidential election will be a dramatic case study in the widespread use of AI for voter/discourse manipulation.
Generative AI will decrease the amount of discussion in classrooms
If we can use such technology to replicate experiences and help disadvantaged areas, it would be a good advancement.
To make genAI a positive force for democracy, we have to democratise it ourselves! i.e. public deliberation, open source development
Many current fears around generative AI are related to its potential to make the rich richer and the poor poorer.
For people to benefit from generative AI, they must have access to it, and know how to utilize it.
future generations will have less ability to read critically since they will outsource their ability to summarize to a machine
Rapid centralization in AI is increasingly irreversible centralization.
I don't understand why people are even interested in computer-generated stuff.  Human-generated stuff is inherently more meaningful.
Anti-AI sentiments and movements will continue to gain traction, but will never achieve significant majority.
Generative AI lowers the cost of content creation to zero, and increases the speed at which ideas spread. Democracy benefits
If models are trained on publicly available data, the models must be made publicly accessible as long as they are in production.
Generative AI may post a major threat to anyone who does not have shares or ownership of the generative AI
Many current fears around generative AI are related to its potential to displace other concerns (war, pandemics, climate) at all expense
Many current fears around generative AI are related to its potential to kill humanity.
AI enables large scale creation of content that is credible by many people, but is actually not truthful.
Generative AI could rob humans of our capacity to think critically and form coherent thoughts. We may become stupider.
We need tools that help combine and raise collective intelligence.
A more precise vocabulary is necessary for many of these conversations about “AI” (i.e. https://www.noemamag.com/the-model-is-the-message/)
Some AI safety arguments seem pretty creative.
AI could be used to create a vastly more meaningful future (as per rebuildingmeaning.com)
Generative AI poses its largest societal danger to the large number of below-average intelligence people who engage in knowledge work
Algorithms may be able to do terrible things on their own but  not necessarily due to 'agency' or misuse by humans, just bad design
Even without further development generative AI will dramatically change many industries.
Generative AI for diagnosis should require authorization and identity verification by doctors to ensure safe use and provide accountability
It is critical that AI not be allowed to be used to let either US or China rule the world or each other, and ideally not even to rule at all
We collectively have choice about what happens with AI systems.
Many current fears around generative AI are related to its potential to impact perception of reality and how we think about the real world.
Those building generative AI may not be thinking about the systemic dynamics and downstream effects.
Current conversations around Generative AI are too centered on fear, the opportunities for increased human creativity are being missed
Current LLMs are built on profoundly biased corpora. Their  structure can't help but preferentially reflect dominant groups' worldviews.
It's more useful to regulate the uses of AI than AI technologies themselves.
We need to be searching for signs of consciousness in AI systems so that we do not cause pain on a previously unimaginable scale
AI is going to widen the gap between rich and poor countries
Generative AI is not strictly bad nor strictly good.
We should be concerned about centralized groups running collective governance work like this. It should be provably transparent.
The Second Amendment to the United States Constitution should apply to compute also.
Generative AI regulation needs to take into account variety of global contexts, and reach beyond a US-based perspective.
It will be helpful to study GAI systems in terms of how their training data include or exclude different coalitions of people.
In previous US elections, voters have been manipulated and discourse has been steered by chatbots
Generative AI primary goal is to create content, platforms then spread it. Regulating social platforms is as important as regulating AI.
Regulating AI has too many second order effects to be useful
If China builds AGI we're all doomed
In a disruptive economy, "Alignment" is only a second best. *Understanding* the nature of these psycho-active techs should be first.
All generative AI content should be watermarked. Watermark tampering should be punishable by law and result in a digital reputation penalty.
“Hyping up” and calling current systems “AGI” is a bad thing to do
Generative AI poses a threat to everyone, irrespective of party
One of the best things world governments could do is help their citizens prove unique humanity online for larger polls like this (with ZK)
Our economic/political systems are not prepared for the coming tsunami of GAI automated work. We need to strengthen social safety nets ASAP.
Many current fears around generative AI are related to its potential to displace humans from their jobs.
Generative AI could help deconstruct complex and nuanced public policy narratives for reception by a broader audience.
A digital identity solution is necessary for open processes like this to be legitimate and not captured
Categorizing these tools 'AI' is detrimental to it's potential. We need to find new ways to name models and networks as extensions of humans
Digital education free and for all is not new but it will be a key pillar to defend democracy against AI generated misinformation
the promise of generative AI will make it increasingly easy for technocratic regimes to institute intrusive surveillance techniques.
Gen AI should follow the example of the 1975 Asilomar conference on recombinant DNA, setting up voluntary safety guidelines
Self-regulation of companies building foundation models for generative AI is not enough, we need an international regulatory body.
The risks posed by AI systems outweigh their potential benefits
Machine learning algorithms can be misused by people to do terrible things
Democracy can be co-creative, co-generative, multi-generative.
AI is likely to be used as a tool of US domination over other countries
Academia and/or governments in different countries should create local and audited AIs for public use.
Specific "styles" of generative AI will have the power to shape whole cultural or societal outlooks / imaginaries.
I feel so worried about the potential harms that AI can bring about that it should be shut off.
potential AGI should be treated in a similar way (and with similar policies) to nuclear weapons and biohazards
AI can translate human language to a structured syntax useful for computer programming.
it's really important that people start to work together instead of infighting about what's the worst harm from AI
AI policy should become a major talking point in politics
Information generated by AIs will make political campaigns cheap to run highly targeted messages per individual, whether true or not
Generative AI gives me superpowers that I would not otherwise have
Generative AI can create believable misinformation at scale
Not everyone will use generative AI. This may be due to factors like access (cost, governance, free time), and technical knowledge.
we will be unable to discern statements written by ai and statements from humans
It is good for society when people share ways in which they use tools (like LLMs) with eachother.
Humans disagree what is harmful. Thus generative AI cannot define harmful. Thus generative AI can do harm at great scale.
